item.title: Need for entertainment
item.description: My nonfiction reading list has really come together around a common theme this week: The human need for fiction. First this video where the anthropologist observes the endless cycle of violence that consumes these New Guineans. But how without this cycle of violence their lives would be unbearably dull. Then Sapiens Then How to Change your Mind All of these readings, contributed to a sense that entertainment is not a distraction from what is real in life.

item.title: Map2
item.description: Note that map2() seems to requires vector arguments in the form df$var library(dplyr) library(purrr) # Create frequency table ds_cyl_n <- mtcars %>% count(cyl) # Create custom function for use in map() my_sample_n <- function(x, y){ mtcars %>% filter(cyl == x) %>% sample_n( size = y, replace = TRUE ) } # hacky map map2_df(.x = ds_cyl_n$cyl, .y = ds_cyl_n$n, .f = my_sample_n) pmap() should be able to handle the dataframe as an argument but only when the column names are the same as the argument names expected by the function.

item.title: Average performance vs who does the school work for
item.description: When choosing where to live so many families fixate on the schools’s quality, but take a closer look at what this really measures. In CA school quality is rated on average performance. This is a “better than nothing” metric, but if you have more data on your kid (you better) then you can probably make a better informed choice, and maybe get a better deal on housing. For instance RWC has low scores, but they have 40% ESL.

item.title: Talking in Effect Sizes
item.description: It is so valuable to have in your back pockket several examples of noteworthy effect sizes. These will silence the optimitsts. Realizes all reported effect sizes aer probably upper limits. Now ask could we expect an upper limit and would you be satisfied with this upper limit. It will almost certainly not be an out of the park effect, or it would be so obvious that all would have adopted it by now.

item.title: Statistical Power in Workplace Experiments
item.description: Let’s do a little primer on probability. If I flip a coin, what is the probability I’ll get heads? 50%, let’s make it even easier and say 1 in 2. If I roll a die, what is the probability I’ll roll a 2? 1 in 6. Let;s take an example of a noteworthy but subtle effect size. If women feel 1/3 of a point less included than men on a 5-pt scale with an SD of 1, what is the probability I will detect a significant difference with 30 people per cell?

item.title: Designing by attrition
item.description: I used to think of planning as foresight. Now I do so much new work that it is often best to jump right in and start working. And templates and structures are designed by attrition. Use ND example of paving the dead grass in an open quad. At first just see what elements of your code you are copying and pasting. Do it three times: Make a function. Same goes for templates.

item.title: Expert Novices
item.description: [use rock rolling god pic: Sisiphus] Experts spend more time planning than novices, who tend to jump right in and start doing. The implication is that novices should try to plan the way experts do. There is a problem with this advice: Novices (by definition) don’t know what to anticipate and thus cannot plan. You need experience in order to plan, so to become an expert, novices should start racking up experience.

item.title: git
item.description: Overview: There are legions of git guides already on the internet. I am writing this one for my team and myself who are newly collaborating on git. I assume that other newcomers to git collaboration will find it useful. This guide will cover the basics of collaborating and undoing mistakes. Undoing in Git git revert The safest way to restore a previous version of your project is to use git revert 0d1d7fc32, where “0d1d7fc32” represent the hash number of the commit you want restored.

item.title: Let me convert you to pipes
item.description: My mother (like many mothers) still has an AOL account. I think her reasoning is that AOL was so difficult to learn, investing the effort to learn gmail is just too daunting. I’ll leave it at that. If you’re not using pipes (%>%) in your R code, you basically have an AOL account. The following sequences are identical in their meaning, but see which one is more human readable: eat(butter(toast(slice(grab(bread))))) bread %>% grab() %>% slice() %>% toast() %>% butter() %>% eat() This is the beauty of pipes (and R generally): It let’s you think about data in a more human way.

item.title: Visualizing (many) model predictions
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(magrittr) library(modelr) ds_mt <- mtcars p_mpg <- ds_mt %>% ggplot(aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) + geom_point() p_mpg m1 <- lm(mpg ~ wt, ds_mt) m2 <- lm(mpg ~ wt + I(wt^2), ds_mt) ds_mt %<>% add_predictions(m1, var = "m1_pred") %>% add_predictions(m2, var = "m2_pred") Show a predicted model using raw data to demo need for a full dataset. p_mpg + geom_point( data = ds_mt, aes(x = wt, y = m2_pred), color = "red" ) show how to make a full dataset Creates 10 values for each var that are equally spaced along its range.
